title: mRNA technology is not new
content: Possibilities for synthetic mRNA have been the focus of decades-long scientific research. Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna were able to produce their respective vaccines as quickly as they did because both companies had invested in research on mRNA-based treatments long before COVID-19 appeared on the scene.

title: Other RNA-based vaccine applications
content: RNA-based technology is used in a recent malaria vaccine patent and BioNTech uses the technology in its cancer immunotherapy research where the mRNA vaccine is individually adapted to target specific tumor mutations.

title: mRNA technology is not a panacea
content: The success of the mRNA technology used in COVID-19 vaccines does not guarantee success in other applications. In other words, the technology is not a panacea. It could be that SARS-CoV-2 is the perfect viral candidate, for a few reasons.

title: The Developmental History of mRNA Vaccine Strategy
content: The mRNA vaccine strategy itself, which was used in this case to code for the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and instruct the immune system to recognize and respond against it, has an extensive developmental history paved with trials and failures.

title: Failures to Produce an HIV Vaccine Led to Innovative Advances
content: One editorial contends that the failures to produce an HIV vaccine were neither a waste of time nor economic resources because they propelled innovative advances which led to effective antiviral vaccines like the one for COVID-19.

title: Failed HIV Vaccines Laid the Foundational Understanding for COVID-19 mRNA Vaccines
content: More specifically, a line of research from failed HIV vaccines laid the foundational understanding for the vaccine model that uses a purified viral protein, as in the case of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines.
